subdomains.name: Enumerative Combinatorics
subdomains.description: The art of counting. How many ways can something happen? Exact formulas and generating functions.
subdomains.flavor: The Counting House — where even infinity can be tallied, one arrangement at a time.

topics.name: Permutations & Combinations
topics.description: Ordered and unordered selections. The binomial coefficient and its combinatorial identity.
topics.flavor: How many ways to arrange, to choose, to order? The first questions of counting.

topics.name: Pigeonhole Principle
topics.description: If more pigeons than holes, some hole has two pigeons. Simple but devastatingly powerful.
topics.flavor: The simplest idea in combinatorics — and one of the most powerful.

topics.name: Inclusion-Exclusion
topics.description: Counting by overcounting and correcting. The alternating sum formula for unions of sets.
topics.flavor: Add, subtract, add, subtract — the rhythmic dance of precise counting.

topics.name: Generating Functions
topics.description: Encoding sequences as power series. Ordinary and exponential generating functions.
topics.flavor: Packaging a whole sequence into a single function — algebra does the counting for you.

topics.name: Catalan Numbers
topics.description: The sequence that counts balanced parentheses, binary trees, triangulations, and hundreds more.
topics.flavor: One sequence, hundreds of faces — the Catalan numbers appear everywhere.

subdomains.name: Graph Theory
subdomains.description: The study of networks. Vertices, edges, paths, and the deep structure of connections.
subdomains.flavor: The Web of Connections — where dots and lines reveal the hidden structure of everything.

topics.name: Graphs & Connectivity
topics.description: Vertices, edges, degree, paths, cycles. The fundamental language of discrete structures.
topics.flavor: Dots and lines — the simplest possible mathematical objects, yet infinitely rich.

topics.name: Trees & Forests
topics.description: Connected acyclic graphs. Spanning trees, Prufer sequences, and tree counting.
topics.flavor: Graphs stripped to their essence — no loops, no redundancy, pure connection.

topics.name: Graph Coloring
topics.description: Assigning colors so adjacent vertices differ. The chromatic number and the four-color theorem.
topics.flavor: How few colors do you need? A question that stumped mathematicians for over a century.

topics.name: Matchings & Flows
topics.description: Pairing vertices optimally. Hall's theorem, network flows, and the max-flow min-cut theorem.
topics.flavor: Perfect pairings and optimal flows — when connections become resources.

topics.name: Planar Graphs
topics.description: Graphs that can be drawn without crossings. Euler's formula and Kuratowski's theorem.
topics.flavor: Can you draw it flat? The geometry of graphs meets topology.

subdomains.name: Extremal Combinatorics
subdomains.description: How large or small can a structure be while satisfying certain properties? Ramsey theory and Turan-type problems.
subdomains.flavor: The Edge of Possibility — pushing structures to their limits.

topics.name: Ramsey Theory
topics.description: Complete disorder is impossible. In any large enough structure, patterns must emerge.
topics.flavor: Order from chaos — guaranteed. The only question is: how much chaos do you need?

topics.name: Turan-Type Problems
topics.description: Maximum edges in a graph with no forbidden subgraph. The extremal graph theory of Turan.
topics.flavor: How many edges can you have without creating a triangle? A clique? Any pattern?

topics.name: Probabilistic Method
topics.description: Proving existence by showing positive probability. Erdos's revolutionary technique.
topics.flavor: If something has a positive chance of existing, it must exist. Erdos's magic trick.

topics.name: Szemeredi's Theorem
topics.description: Any dense set of integers contains arbitrarily long arithmetic progressions. A monumental result.
topics.flavor: Hide among the integers all you want — patterns will find you.

topics.name: Additive Combinatorics
topics.description: The combinatorics of addition. Sumsets, Freiman's theorem, and the structure of sum-free sets.
topics.flavor: What happens when you add sets of numbers together? Surprisingly structured chaos.

subdomains.name: Combinatorial Design
subdomains.description: Balanced arrangements and structured configurations. Latin squares, block designs, and finite geometry.
subdomains.flavor: The Architect's Workshop — where perfect balance is built from mathematical blueprints.

topics.name: Latin Squares
topics.description: n×n arrays where each symbol appears once per row and column. Sudoku generalized.
topics.flavor: Every row, every column, every symbol exactly once — perfect balance.

topics.name: Block Designs
topics.description: Collections of subsets with prescribed intersection properties. Steiner systems and BIBDs.
topics.flavor: Arranging elements into blocks with perfect symmetry.

topics.name: Finite Geometry
topics.description: Geometry with finitely many points. Projective and affine planes over finite fields.
topics.flavor: A universe with only a handful of points — yet all of geometry still works.

topics.name: Error-Correcting Codes
topics.description: Encoding information to detect and correct errors. Hamming codes, Reed-Solomon, and bounds.
topics.flavor: Every message you send is protected by the mathematics of combinatorial design.

topics.name: Matroids
topics.description: Abstract independence structures generalizing linear independence and forests in graphs.
topics.flavor: The common essence of independence — in graphs, vectors, and beyond.
